posts.title_en: I‚Äôm with myself, damn it, for life
posts.content_en:
An introduction without polish

This isn‚Äôt philosophy with a quote book or a motivational talk with a plastic smile. This is a truth that arrives late, hurts like hell, yet right on time: I‚Äôm with myself, damn it, for life. Not just for weekends. Not for a courtship phase with myself. But to the very end ‚Äî with all the aches, the foolishness, the wins, and the heart-bursts. Either I befriend myself, or I spend life in an internal concentration camp where I torture, belittle, and betray myself.

How I rented myself out

I used to be different. I gave myself away to the last thread. For family. For order. For the ‚Äúthat‚Äôs how it should be.‚Äù Until I noticed I was gone. The body ‚Äî exhausted. The soul ‚Äî hunted down. The head ‚Äî in fog. Gratitude ‚Äî none, and won‚Äôt be. Because you stop being a living person and become a ‚Äúuseful function.‚Äù Worst of all, you start believing it‚Äôs right. If you‚Äôre always depleted ‚Äî you must be a good person. That‚Äôs what you think. But it isn‚Äôt love ‚Äî it‚Äôs self-erasure with a ‚Äúmorality‚Äù label.

The source of guilt

When you‚Äôre drained dry, you stop being a source of warmth and become a source of guilt. There‚Äôs no you left, yet you‚Äôre still expected to serve. The only thing you can hand out is the constant sense of ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt measure up.‚Äù Then your wife says: you‚Äôre at fault. Your kids: you‚Äôre not the one they need. Your employer: could be better. And most of all ‚Äî you tell it to yourself every single day. Like a mantra. Even when you try to break free ‚Äî you don‚Äôt. Because the inner voice screams: ‚ÄúHow will they manage without you?! They need you!‚Äù Needed ‚Äî yes. But alive. Whole. Present. Not a half-corpse wearing a noble muzzle.

Self-love isn‚Äôt a luxury ‚Äî it‚Äôs a survival manual

‚ÄúNo one loves me like I do.‚Äù ‚Äî sounds like a joke. In reality ‚Äî it‚Äôs all that can save you. If you don‚Äôt hold yourself, no one will pull you up. If you can‚Äôt care for yourself, you won‚Äôt truly care for anyone else. Self-love isn‚Äôt a bubble bath. It‚Äôs about: going to bed on time, not eating crap, not living in chronic ‚Äúhave to,‚Äù not agreeing to be a slave, not letting others write your story. The formula is simple: Want to help others? ‚Äî Don‚Äôt die. Want to be a pillar? ‚Äî Be your own first. No one will live this life for you. No one will slip into your skin, feel your pain, survive your fatigue. If you‚Äôre at war with yourself, all others will ever get is your shadow. Life isn‚Äôt a shadow. It‚Äôs you ‚Äî whole, alive, present.

Conclusion

With yourself ‚Äî for life. And if that‚Äôs the case, better be your own friend than your own executioner. Better hold yourself with dignity than drag yourself by the rope of ‚Äúmoral debt.‚Äù Only the one who has returned to himself has something real to give ‚Äî not from pain, but from wholeness.

posts.title_en: Real egoism is when you‚Äôre not there
posts.content_en: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be selfish,‚Äù the system shouts. Translation: don‚Äôt pay attention to yourself. Live for others. Renounce yourself. Put yourself on a shelf until everyone else gets theirs. So you live that way. And what do your kids see? A father always tired. Always dissatisfied. Silently suffering and enduring. That‚Äôs not sacrifice. That‚Äôs slow self-destruction wearing a ‚Äúkindness‚Äù mask. Someone might say: ‚ÄúYou have a big heart.‚Äù Hearts aren‚Äôt bottomless. They need care, nourishment, listening. Real egoism isn‚Äôt putting yourself first ‚Äî it‚Äôs not putting yourself anywhere at all, then walking around angry and depleted, blaming others for ‚Äúnot appreciating.‚Äù Because you don‚Äôt serve from love ‚Äî you serve from emptiness. And nothing pours from empty.

posts.title_en: Being present isn‚Äôt just standing nearby
posts.content_en: Presence isn‚Äôt simply being in the room, staring at a wall, or ‚Äúlistening with love‚Äù while your head runs a task list. Presence is inner engagement. No split. Body here, mind here, soul here. It‚Äôs feeling yourself in the moment ‚Äî and not fleeing. A present man doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúfix everything.‚Äù He is. He holds the space, doesn‚Äôt dissolve in fatigue, doesn‚Äôt disappear into his phone, doesn‚Äôt shut down into silence. It‚Äôs not always heroic. Sometimes it‚Äôs just: sitting and being quiet ‚Äî without hiding, looking your child in the eyes and actually seeing, listening not to reply, but to stay in contact. Presence is the opposite of autopilot. It requires energy ‚Äî the kind you still have when you haven‚Äôt squandered yourself playing roles, pretending to be ‚Äústrong,‚Äù or masking exhaustion with a smile. Presence is an act of respect ‚Äî for yourself, for others, for life. You can build a house and spend your whole life absent inside it. Only in the later years to realize: ‚ÄúI was everywhere but here.‚Äù Life is only here. Nowhere else.

posts.title_en: I‚Äôm not my own enemy
posts.content_en:
It may seem other people land the hardest blows. The most insidious ones, though, are self-inflicted. You‚Äôre your own enemy when you constantly berate yourself. When you don‚Äôt forgive weakness. When you demand machine-level output and treat yourself like the enemy. Didn‚Äôt make it ‚Äî ‚Äúlazy.‚Äù Got tired ‚Äî ‚Äúweakling.‚Äù Want to be alone ‚Äî ‚Äúselfish.‚Äù Broke down ‚Äî ‚Äúworthless.‚Äù That‚Äôs not self-criticism ‚Äî that‚Äôs self-flagellation disguised as ‚Äúunderstanding yourself.‚Äù The body starts speaking its language: insomnia, pain, apathy, panic. It can‚Äôt live in a system where the master is a torturer.

Reconciliation doesn‚Äôt start with meditation

It starts with an honest talk: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sick of how I treat you. I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù Instead of a new plan to ‚Äúupgrade myself,‚Äù comes an intention to simply be with yourself ‚Äî not fleeing, not fixing, not molding a ‚Äúbetter version.‚Äù True acceptance isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care what I am.‚Äù It‚Äôs ‚ÄúI‚Äôm with you, even like this.‚Äù

You‚Äôre either your own rear guard ‚Äî or a rear assault

You can wage war on yourself for a lifetime ‚Äî forcing, belittling, grinding. All you‚Äôll win is an ulcer. Or you can start building an alliance. Where there‚Äôs room for fatigue. For compassion. Where the inner voice doesn‚Äôt say ‚Äúwhat now, again?‚Äù but ‚Äúwhat do you need right now?‚Äù That‚Äôs not weakness. That‚Äôs the base. Without it, all your strength is just adrenaline-fueled fakery. You don‚Äôt have to be perfect to deserve love ‚Äî especially your own.

posts.title_en: The martyr is not a hero
posts.content_en:
The martyr‚Äôs image is one of the most persistent ‚Äî especially in cultures where suffering is treated as virtue. Endure ‚Äî you‚Äôre strong. Sacrifice yourself ‚Äî you‚Äôre good. Keep silent when it hurts ‚Äî you‚Äôre brave. Truth is: a martyr isn‚Äôt a hero ‚Äî he‚Äôs a prisoner of his role. He hurts, but can‚Äôt speak. He‚Äôs learned that his love is pain, his value is silence, his ‚ÄúI‚Äù is an echo of others‚Äô needs.

What the martyr pays with

He pays with: health, nerves, wasted time, wrecked relationships, and above all ‚Äî the loss of himself. Live long enough in ‚ÄúI‚Äôll endure,‚Äù and you vanish. You turn into a function. Ask him, ‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù ‚Äî he doesn‚Äôt know. He never allowed himself to want. Martyrdom is convenient for everyone ‚Äî except you. For family ‚Äî you accommodate. For colleagues ‚Äî you don‚Äôt argue. For friends ‚Äî you‚Äôre always there. For the system ‚Äî you don‚Äôt ask questions. Convenience isn‚Äôt love. It‚Äôs an instrument. As long as you‚Äôre convenient, you‚Äôll be used ‚Äî often unconsciously. And you‚Äôll proudly say, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no trouble.‚Äù When in fact it‚Äôs hard, bitter, lonely. Leaving the role isn‚Äôt betrayal ‚Äî it‚Äôs returning. Quitting martyrdom doesn‚Äôt mean becoming indifferent. It means becoming alive. Saying ‚Äúno‚Äù isn‚Äôt egoism. Asking isn‚Äôt weakness. Claiming your right isn‚Äôt a sin. No one will free you from the cage you built and guard yourself. The exit is only from the inside. A question to end with. Do you live to suffer ‚Äî or to be present, warm, strong ‚Äî for yourself and for others? One choice ‚Äî two utterly different fates. And one more truth few mention. The scariest thing is when life has already passed, and they tell you: ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt ask you to.‚Äù You gave yourself away, invested, endured, pulled ‚Äî all hoping ‚Äúthey‚Äôll see,‚Äù ‚Äúthey‚Äôll value,‚Äù ‚Äúthey need it.‚Äù And then ‚Äî silence. Or worse: resentment, surprise, ingratitude. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt ask you to.‚Äù ‚Äî these words can kill the last hope. You realize you betrayed yourself for an illusion. It‚Äôs not just pain. It‚Äôs collapse. Loss of meaning. Which is why living for yourself isn‚Äôt egoism ‚Äî it‚Äôs the only way not to become a victim of others‚Äô blindness.

posts.title_en: Strength is not armor
posts.content_en:
We were taught: be strong. But no one explained what that meant. We grew up convinced that strength means: don‚Äôt cry, don‚Äôt ask for help, carry everyone, never give up, never show weakness. But that‚Äôs not strength. That‚Äôs armor. And armor doesn‚Äôt save you ‚Äî it cuts you off from yourself. Because inside there can be pain, fear, confusion ‚Äî but you‚Äôre ‚Äúnot allowed‚Äù to feel it. Armor is when you walk like a tank but already out of fuel. When you drag yourself and three more because ‚Äúyou have to.‚Äù When you wake heavy but mutter, ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt matter, we‚Äôll push through.‚Äù

Real strength isn‚Äôt a mask

Real strength is being alive and not afraid of it. It‚Äôs not a steel face. It‚Äôs the ability to: feel pain ‚Äî and not run, admit fatigue ‚Äî and stop, say ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt‚Äù ‚Äî and not be ashamed, cry ‚Äî and not devalue yourself after. Strong isn‚Äôt the one who never breaks. Strong is the one who doesn‚Äôt pretend he doesn‚Äôt break. Who doesn‚Äôt hide behind ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine‚Äù while inside is a crater. Who can be vulnerable ‚Äî but not fragile, open ‚Äî but not defenseless. Because strength isn‚Äôt standing alone. It‚Äôs being yourself without dissolving. And one more thing: Your strength isn‚Äôt in armor. It‚Äôs in clarity, dignity, and the freedom to be yourself. As long as you hide behind ‚ÄúI‚Äôm holding on‚Äù ‚Äî life passes you by. Being alive is risky. But it‚Äôs the only way to feel you truly exist.

posts.title_en: Being honest doesn‚Äôt mean being harsh
posts.content_en:
Honesty often gets confused with bluntness. As if truth must cut deep, draw blood. As if softness is weakness, and sharpness is always strength. But strength isn‚Äôt in chopping. Strength is in being present and honest without needing to dominate.

Honesty isn‚Äôt a weapon

When someone says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just being honest,‚Äù but really unloads aggression on you ‚Äî that‚Äôs not honesty. That‚Äôs dumping pain with a ‚Äúsincerity‚Äù sticker. True honesty doesn‚Äôt devalue. It doesn‚Äôt destroy ‚Äî it illuminates. It speaks not to kill, but to clarify, to open, to bring back to reality. You can speak truth and leave someone whole. Honesty can be warm. Clear. Calm. Not sugarcoated, but not drenched in salt either. It‚Äôs not about whether to speak, but how. If I‚Äôm present ‚Äî real, attentive ‚Äî I know how to say it. I am ‚Äî and that‚Äôs the core. All these essays point to the same thing, just from different angles: I am. And when I am ‚Äî I don‚Äôt need to attack to be heard. I don‚Äôt need to stay silent to keep a ‚Äúnice face.‚Äù I don‚Äôt need to play judge to feel alive. Being honest means staying in contact ‚Äî with myself and with another. No armor. No showing off. No performance. And that‚Äôs not harsh. That‚Äôs real.

posts.title_en: I owe no one anything
posts.content_en: It sounds like rebellion. Like defiance. Like indifference. But in truth ‚Äî it‚Äôs maturity. ‚ÄúI owe no one anything‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean rejecting love. It means rejecting life as a debt pit instead of a heart. You‚Äôre not a contract. From childhood, we were told: you‚Äôll be loved if‚Ä¶ you obey, you‚Äôre convenient, you‚Äôre responsible, you give yourself away. And we believed it. That love is payment. That presence is obligation. That life means endlessly ‚Äúworking off‚Äù your worth. But life isn‚Äôt credit. And you‚Äôre not a service staffer for someone‚Äôs happiness. True love isn‚Äôt debt. When someone says, ‚ÄúI did everything for you‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî it sounds tender, but it‚Äôs a hook. True love doesn‚Äôt control. Doesn‚Äôt count. Doesn‚Äôt expect ‚Äúchange back.‚Äù It flows. It‚Äôs a gift. If love is obligation, it isn‚Äôt love. It‚Äôs a survival contract. Freedom isn‚Äôt indifference. ‚ÄúI owe no one anything‚Äù means: I choose what and to whom I give. Not from duty ‚Äî from self-respect. It isn‚Äôt ‚Äúscrew everyone.‚Äù It‚Äôs ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt let myself be torn apart so someone can warm themselves on my remains.‚Äù It‚Äôs doing good not for applause. Helping not from guilt. Saying ‚Äúno‚Äù not from anger, but because your ‚Äúyes‚Äù has value. I‚Äôm not here to repay. I‚Äôm here to exist.

posts.title_en: The right to tenderness
posts.content_en: Tenderness ‚Äî we smothered it. Because ‚Äúnot the time.‚Äù Because weakness. Because the world is harsh, and if you soften ‚Äî you‚Äôll be eaten. But the truth is ‚Äî it isn‚Äôt harshness that saves, but connection to yourself. And tenderness is its language. We weren‚Äôt born armored. A child is born not in armor but in skin. Not in control, not ‚Äúholding it together.‚Äù The child feels. Cries, reaches, reacts. That vulnerability isn‚Äôt threat ‚Äî it‚Äôs aliveness. Then the world breaks us, teaches us to ‚Äúhide,‚Äù ‚Äúkeep face,‚Äù ‚Äúbe hard.‚Äù And we lose access to our real selves. Tenderness isn‚Äôt feminine or childish. It‚Äôs not about gender. It‚Äôs about access to the heart. Tenderness is when you look at someone and see more than is comfortable. When instead of ‚Äúlet me explain what‚Äôs right‚Äù ‚Äî you just sit down beside and stay quiet. When you‚Äôre not ashamed to touch, to hug, to be soft ‚Äî because you‚Äôre not acting, you simply are. Allowing tenderness is an inner revolution. The world taught us to be strong, productive, logical, confident. But it didn‚Äôt teach us to be alive. Tenderness isn‚Äôt petals and hearts. It‚Äôs when you stop beating yourself. When you let yourself breathe without tension. When you‚Äôre not ashamed to be kind. And most of all: Tenderness is proof that I‚Äôm no longer at war with the world ‚Äî or with myself. It doesn‚Äôt mean I trust everyone. It means I don‚Äôt want to live armored under my skin. Sometimes strength is standing tall. And sometimes strength is simply touching another‚Äôs shoulder and saying: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here with you.‚Äù That‚Äôs not weakness. That‚Äôs humanity.

posts.title_en: The one who doesn‚Äôt rescue
posts.content_en: You‚Äôre not God. Not a firefighter. Not humanity‚Äôs last bastion. You‚Äôre simply you. And that‚Äôs enough. The rescuer‚Äôs role is a trap for the good. Many of us got used to being ‚Äúuseful.‚Äù Giving advice, support, money, time, ourselves. Especially to those who ‚Äúcan‚Äôt manage without you.‚Äù And we truly want to help. Because we care. But then suddenly: you‚Äôre used, you‚Äôre ignored, you‚Äôre blamed, or they vanish once they‚Äôre better. Because you weren‚Äôt a person. You were a service. The rescuer isn‚Äôt a hero. He‚Äôs a tired, drained slave to others‚Äô problems. And worse ‚Äî he stops others from growing. Because when I ‚Äúrescue‚Äù you, I say: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt manage without me.‚Äù I believe it. You start believing it. And we both stay stuck ‚Äî you as victim, me as messiah. Meanwhile, life passes us both by. I don‚Äôt rescue ‚Äî I stand beside. I don‚Äôt remove another‚Äôs pain. I‚Äôm just with them. I can support ‚Äî but not instead. I can offer a hand ‚Äî but not carry you. If I carry, I leave no room for your strength. And if you hate me for not ‚Äúpulling you out‚Äù ‚Äî maybe it‚Äôs time you walk yourself. The one who doesn‚Äôt rescue isn‚Äôt indifferent. I‚Äôm not cold. I‚Äôm alive. And I don‚Äôt want to live someone else‚Äôs life. Sometimes the greatest help is not interfering. Letting someone live their pain, make their choice, hit their bottom. Only then do they find themselves ‚Äî not my crutches. To end with: The one who doesn‚Äôt rescue gives a chance. To himself, to the other. For something real ‚Äî not a simulation of closeness. I‚Äôm not your savior. I‚Äôm just a person. Beside you. Present. Real. Sometimes that‚Äôs more than enough.

posts.title_en: I‚Äôm not a draft horse
posts.content_en: A draft horse doesn‚Äôt protest. It just pulls. Day after day. No words. No questions. No ‚Äúwhat about me?‚Äù And we often live the same way. But we‚Äôre not horses. And certainly not draft ones. The ‚Äúresponsible for everything‚Äù syndrome. It‚Äôs when you carry not only your own load ‚Äî but also others‚Äô. Even what no one asked you to. Because ‚Äúsomeone has to,‚Äù or ‚Äúno one else can,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm used to it.‚Äù And then you collapse, powerless. Or stand there silently drinking your pain instead of water. No one thanks you. Some even resent you when you stop. I‚Äôm not guilty of being tired. Fatigue isn‚Äôt a crime. It‚Äôs a signal. If the body halts ‚Äî it means you can‚Äôt keep going. Because beyond this point there won‚Äôt be you. Just a function with your face. I have the right not to want. Not to want to pick up the phone. Not to want to listen to problems. Not to want to work for three. Not to want to ‚Äúoffer a shoulder‚Äù when there‚Äôs no shoulder left. Even the strongest have muscles. Tear them ‚Äî they stop holding. Pulling isn‚Äôt always love. We confuse love with self-sacrifice. Loyalty with depletion. We think if we endure ‚Äî it must be ‚Äúfor something higher.‚Äù But often it‚Äôs just fear of stopping. Because then comes emptiness. And the question: who am I, if I‚Äôm not pulling for everyone? I‚Äôm more than just usefulness. I exist ‚Äî even when I‚Äôm not ‚Äúuseful.‚Äù Even when I‚Äôm just lying down. Even when I say ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù The one who loves me won‚Äôt question that. The one who uses me ‚Äî will get angry. And that will reveal the truth about who is who. And one more thing: I‚Äôm not a draft horse. I‚Äôm human. If I stop, it‚Äôs not betrayal ‚Äî it‚Äôs staying myself. If I disappear ‚Äî there‚Äôll be nothing left to pull. And no one.

posts.title_en: Pity doesn‚Äôt save
posts.content_en: Pity ‚Äî sounds merciful. But often it humiliates. Because instead of seeing strength in someone, you see a pitiful object. And you bring ‚Äúhelp‚Äù not as an equal ‚Äî but from above. Pity is not support. Pity is control. Soft, smiling ‚Äî but still from above. When you pity, you‚Äôve already decided: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm stronger, you‚Äôre weaker.‚Äù But maybe the person is just in a hard moment. That doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre weak. They don‚Äôt need pity ‚Äî they need space where they can be vulnerable without being diminished. Support means being beside, not above. Seeing strength even when someone hurts. Not saying, ‚ÄúPoor thing,‚Äù but asking: ‚ÄúDo you want me to be here?‚Äù Pity sometimes feeds the ego. We pity others to feel good about ourselves. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm kind, I pity.‚Äù But does the other person see themselves in this? Or only your self-satisfaction? Goodness isn‚Äôt when you look good. It‚Äôs when the other feels better near you. Instead of pity ‚Äî equality. I‚Äôm not better than you because I‚Äôm doing better now. You‚Äôre not worse because you‚Äôre in the pit. We all end up there sometimes. And the most valuable thing is someone who doesn‚Äôt flee, doesn‚Äôt lecture, doesn‚Äôt pity ‚Äî but simply stays. To close: Pity doesn‚Äôt save. Respect does. Presence. Honesty that sees a person not as an object, but as a subject. Not a victim, but someone walking their own path. It‚Äôs not about ‚Äúrescuing.‚Äù It‚Äôs about being beside.

posts.title_en: You don‚Äôt need to be earned
posts.content_en: From childhood, we‚Äôre taught: behave, and you‚Äôll be loved. Don‚Äôt fuss, and you‚Äôll be praised. Earn it. Prove it. Meet expectations. And maybe ‚Äî you won‚Äôt be left. We adapt. We live not as ourselves, but as a version that‚Äôs ‚Äúpleasant.‚Äù The fear of being yourself. We fear saying ‚Äúno,‚Äù fearing rejection. We fear honesty, fearing it‚Äôll be ‚Äúinconvenient.‚Äù We fear being tired, imperfect, real ‚Äî fearing we won‚Äôt be accepted. But love you must earn ‚Äî isn‚Äôt love. It‚Äôs trade. I‚Äôm not service staff. My ‚Äúyes‚Äù isn‚Äôt currency to buy affection. My ‚Äúno‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make me bad. If I do something ‚Äî it‚Äôs from choice. Not to stay in someone‚Äôs spotlight. Being yourself isn‚Äôt egoism. I‚Äôm not guilty of being me. If someone values me only when I‚Äôm ‚Äúconvenient‚Äù ‚Äî that‚Äôs not love. That‚Äôs consumption. I‚Äôm not a project under others‚Äô expectations. I don‚Äôt need fixing. I‚Äôm not broken. I‚Äôm a process. A path. A person ‚Äî not a wrapper for others‚Äô fantasies. In the end: I‚Äôm not here to earn approval. I‚Äôm here to be. That‚Äôs enough. Love that begins with ‚Äúif‚Äù isn‚Äôt love. True love begins with: ‚ÄúI see you. And I‚Äôm with you.‚Äù

posts.title_en: I do ‚Äî because I want to, not because I must
posts.content_en: When you act from compulsion, the body tenses. Thoughts slow. The smile sticks to your face like a mask. You‚Äôre no longer you ‚Äî just a mechanism doing ‚Äúwhat must be done.‚Äù And then you snap. Or vanish. Because you can‚Äôt be ‚Äúgood‚Äù anymore. True action starts with choice. Doing something not because you must. But because you can. Because you choose. Because it matters. Not for a medal. Not for praise. Not to avoid reproach. From an inner ‚Äúyes.‚Äù Being good doesn‚Äôt mean being convenient. Goodness isn‚Äôt convenience for others. It‚Äôs the truth of your heart. You can be good ‚Äî and still say ‚Äúno.‚Äù You can help ‚Äî without sacrificing yourself. You can support ‚Äî without losing yourself. Compulsion eats meaning. Even the best act, if forced, smells false. Even a gift given out of guilt leaves bitterness. The opposite: even a small act, done freely, shines. The right not to want. I have the right not to want. I have the right to choose. That‚Äôs not egoism ‚Äî it‚Äôs dignity. True goodness isn‚Äôt sacrifice. It‚Äôs a free act from an open heart. I do ‚Äî because I want. Because I see it as right. Because I feel the connection. Not because someone expects it.

posts.title_en: A true ‚Äúno‚Äù is love too
posts.content_en: We‚Äôre taught love always says ‚Äúyes.‚Äù But sometimes true love says ‚Äúno‚Äù ‚Äî clearly, firmly, painfully, but respectfully. Sometimes the only loving thing you can do is leave. A boundary isn‚Äôt betrayal. When I say ‚Äúno,‚Äù I don‚Äôt betray. I stay myself. I don‚Äôt disappear, bend, or become convenient at my own expense. Love without boundaries is self-destruction, not nobility. ‚ÄúYes‚Äù without ‚Äúno‚Äù isn‚Äôt choice. If I can‚Äôt say ‚Äúno,‚Äù my ‚Äúyes‚Äù means nothing. It isn‚Äôt agreement ‚Äî it‚Äôs submission. It isn‚Äôt action ‚Äî it‚Äôs survival. You can refuse and still stay warm. You can say: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not mine.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not ready.‚Äù And not burn the bridge. Love isn‚Äôt permissiveness. It‚Äôs space where both remain alive. To close: When I say ‚Äúno,‚Äù I don‚Äôt lose love. I only lose its illusion. And that, too, is truth. And dignity. And love ‚Äî simply honest.

posts.title_en: Ego takes offense ‚Äî dignity gets disappointed
posts.content_en: When you give sincerely, from the heart ‚Äî and in return get silence, devaluation, or worse, reproach ‚Äî something clenches inside. It isn‚Äôt offense. It‚Äôs disappointment. Not in yourself ‚Äî in the person you trusted with a piece of you. Ego takes offense. Ego wants recognition. A ‚Äúthank you.‚Äù To be remembered. Ego feeds on applause. When none comes ‚Äî it rages. Loudly. With tantrums. Dignity simply steps away. Dignity doesn‚Äôt rage. Doesn‚Äôt seek revenge. Doesn‚Äôt demand. It just doesn‚Äôt return. It sees. It concludes. It won‚Äôt prove its worth ‚Äî because it knows it. Giving isn‚Äôt buying love. I help because I want to. Not to be loved. When you give ‚Äî it‚Äôs your choice. But if it‚Äôs taken for granted, with no respect, no response ‚Äî that‚Äôs a sign. Sometimes about them. Sometimes about you. You can give ‚Äî and then stop. That isn‚Äôt cruelty. It‚Äôs hygiene. Inner hygiene. Because when you‚Äôre used constantly, you stop hearing yourself. You give not from the heart, but on autopilot. From fatigue. From habit. If I‚Äôm unnoticed ‚Äî I‚Äôm not smaller. But I won‚Äôt impose again. Dignity doesn‚Äôt vanish. It simply doesn‚Äôt open where it‚Äôs trampled. And that‚Äôs fine. It‚Äôs not offense. It‚Äôs self-respect.

posts.title_en: Epilogue
posts.content_en: That‚Äôs it. Done. Thanks to those who read. To those who maybe read it all. I know this: there‚Äôs one person who read every word ‚Äî even in conditions where it isn‚Äôt simple. And for that ‚Äî my deepest thanks. This isn‚Äôt the end. But a full stop is needed. To catch breath. To move on ‚Äî this time with myself, not against myself.

posts.title_en: Games of Life
The Uncurious and the Curious: Two Worlds Within One Society
posts.content_en:
Modern Reality

Society favors the uncurious. Those for whom it is enough that ‚Äúit just works.‚Äù Press the button, get the result ‚Äî and don‚Äôt bother. They are offered services, apps, subscriptions ‚Äî and that is sufficient. This is not stupidity; it is simply a choice. Not everyone wants to ‚Äúlook under the hood.‚Äù Most people are content with what they already have.

Why It‚Äôs Convenient

As Neil Postman argued in Amusing Ourselves to Death, modern systems prefer convenience over questions. The uncurious are useful because: 1. They do not generate unnecessary questions. 2. They accept what is given ‚Äî and the system refines their comfort. 3. They provide stability. Society relies on them because they are ‚Äúlike everyone else.‚Äù

The Other Side of the Choice

But there are also the curious. Those who keep asking: ‚ÄúWhy is it this way?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs inside?‚Äù ‚ÄúCould it be better?‚Äù They are not always convenient, because they break patterns. They are not always simple, because they are irritated by the answer, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs how it has always been.‚Äù This resonates with Karl Popper‚Äôs idea of critical thinking: only by questioning can we see the mechanics of how the world works.

Conclusion

Society is indeed built on the uncurious ‚Äî and that is fine. But the door to another mode remains open: if you are willing to dig, you will always uncover more. The choice is still there: live with what you have, or go further and dig into the depths.

posts.title_en: Universe-25 and Us: Why Chaos Isn‚Äôt Always Evil
posts.content_en:
In the 1970s, ethologist John Calhoun conducted his famous Universe-25 experiment.

Mice were placed in ideal conditions: unlimited food, water, warmth, safety, and space. At first, the colony grew rapidly. But then something strange happened: mice began to lose purpose, females abandoned their offspring, males withdrew or turned aggressive without reason, and eventually the population completely collapsed. This experiment (Calhoun, 1973) entered psychology as an illustration that comfort without challenges or meaning leads to degeneration.

How We Differ from Mice

Humans are not mice. We can create new meanings even in abundance. As Viktor Frankl emphasized, meaning is not given from the outside ‚Äî it must be discovered or created. Ways humans generate meaning include: art, science, the search for truth, the drive to change the world. We are capable of inventing our own challenges, though more often we wait until life throws them at us.

Hard Times and the Paradox of Strength

There is a well-known social formula (similar to cycles described by historian Arnold Toynbee): hard times create strong people, strong people build comfort, comfort makes people weaker, weak people create hard times again. The cycle is painful, but it is also what keeps civilizations alive.

The Double Truth

Here lies the paradox, also echoed in Hans Selye‚Äôs research on stress: On the societal level, crises push humanity forward ‚Äî forcing us to invent, to struggle, to search for new meaning. On the personal level, crises are always tragedies: losing a home, loved ones, or peace of mind. Saying ‚Äúthis is for the greater good‚Äù sounds cruel to someone who simply ended up in the wrong place at the wrong time. The system moves indifferently, like nature. But unlike mice, we are aware of this paradox.

Why Chaos Is Also Part of Life

Global disorder and crises can be seen not only as evil but also as reminders: life should not stand still. Yes, it is painful. Yes, it is often unfair. But in chaos, new meaning is often born.

Conclusion

Calhoun‚Äôs experiment is not evidence of humanity‚Äôs doom. It is a reminder: comfort without meaning is a trap, challenges ‚Äî even painful ones ‚Äî keep us alive, and the double truth of life is this: some see development in crises, while others experience them as personal catastrophe. And this is the paradox we live in: between chaos that breaks us and meanings that save us.

posts.title_en: The Box of Life: Logic Inside and Silence Outside
posts.content_en:
This text is neither an answer nor a call to action. It‚Äôs a fixation of a point where logic fades and silence becomes honest. If you‚Äôve ever stood there ‚Äî it may feel familiar.

The Box of Life: Logic Inside and Silence Outside

Inside the Box

Life can be imagined as a box. Inside this box, everything seems clear and natural. We eat to sustain the body. We work to earn money. We raise children to continue the lineage. We laugh to ease tension and rest to regain strength. All these actions form a familiar network of logic: cause ‚Üí effect, need ‚Üí action ‚Üí result.

Within the box, it all looks perfectly rational. If you don‚Äôt question it, it feels as though life itself makes sense: each small goal feeds another, every task keeps the system running. This is how most people live ‚Äî inside the box.

Looking from the Outside

But lift your head higher and ask: ‚ÄúWhat is the box itself for?‚Äù ‚Äî and the logic disappears. Everything inside has its ‚Äúwhy,‚Äù but the overall structure suddenly seems to have none. The box exists on its own, without being visibly connected to anything larger, without an explanation. This gap feels absurd: local meaning against global silence. It‚Äôs unsettling because we‚Äôre used to every small system being part of a larger one. A device fits into a machine. A machine fits into a factory. A factory fits into an economy. But life? The box we‚Äôre in? No answer.

The Structure Isn‚Äôt Empty

And yet the box isn‚Äôt empty. It isn‚Äôt a meaningless toy. It‚Äôs full of actions, processes, and logic. The problem isn‚Äôt that it‚Äôs hollow ‚Äî it‚Äôs that we don‚Äôt see where it‚Äôs connected next. Perhaps it‚Äôs part of a larger mechanism. Perhaps it‚Äôs wired into something beyond our perception. Our minds hit the walls of the box; what‚Äôs beyond them remains unseen. That‚Äôs why it feels like ‚Äúfor nothing.‚Äù

A Bubble on Water

The best metaphor is a bubble on the surface of water. It appears, takes shape, and exists for a while. It‚Äôs truly separate: it has boundaries, a thin skin, a movement of its own. But eventually the bubble bursts and returns to the water. Life is much the same. For a time it looks like a separate world, a box, a structure. Inside ‚Äî logic, rules, causality. And then it disappears, returning to the larger whole it came from. The bubble isn‚Äôt meaningless. It‚Äôs a manifestation ‚Äî a temporary form shaped by conditions. It‚Äôs not random, but it has no ‚Äúultimate goal‚Äù other than to exist as that manifestation.

The Silence of Answers

Here lies the sharpest point. We want an answer: ‚ÄúWhy the box? Why the bubble?‚Äù But beyond the edge there is only silence. No voice saying ‚Äúhere is the meaning.‚Äù Only the fact: the box exists, the bubble exists, and then they‚Äôre gone. This doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean it‚Äôs all meaningless. It means the box‚Äôs logic is local; the global logic is hidden. It may exist. It may not. But we don‚Äôt have access to it.

What to Do with This Realization

  • You can turn away and live entirely inside the box, ignoring the outside.
  • You can invent an explanation and be comforted ‚Äî religion, ideology, a story of ‚Äúmeaning.‚Äù
  • Or you can accept: the box exists, the bubble exists, their purpose is unseen, and because of that you are free inside the box.

If there is no external ‚Äúwhy,‚Äù then we ourselves can create our small ‚Äúwhys.‚Äù Not as an answer to the cosmic question, but as a personal choice.

Conclusion:

Life as a box is not empty or pointless. It is more like a bubble on water ‚Äî a temporary form with its own logic inside and an invisible connection to something greater. We don‚Äôt know where it‚Äôs connected. We may never know. But that doesn‚Äôt take away the meaning of living the moment itself ‚Äî of choosing what to do inside the box while it exists.

posts.title_en: Life in Perspective vs. Life in the Illusion of the Moment
posts.content_en:
A person is always faced with a choice: to look ahead or to live only for today. And that choice shapes not only money or possessions, but the very quality of life itself.

Life in Perspective

Those who look ahead evaluate things and decisions by their long-term usefulness. Phone: ‚ÄúWill it work reliably for years?‚Äù Car: ‚ÄúWill it survive the winter, and is it easy to maintain?‚Äù Money: ‚ÄúWill I end up trapped in debt?‚Äù For these people, value = practicality + long-term benefit. They plan, calculate, and anticipate. Their freedom comes from not being held hostage by fleeting desires.

Life in the Illusion of the Moment

There is another approach: to live by today‚Äôs image. An iPhone on credit: ‚ÄúAt least everyone sees I‚Äôm modern.‚Äù A car bought ‚Äúfor photos,‚Äù even if repairs swallow the salary. Clothes chosen for the brand label, not the quality. Here the formula shifts: value = impression + status in the eyes of others. The illusion of the moment gives a quick rush ‚Äî the sense of belonging, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm one of them.‚Äù But tomorrow that status collapses, replaced by a new model or a new trend.

The Price of Choice

Perspective: more discipline today, but stability tomorrow. Illusion of the moment: easier now, but problems will come later. The paradox is that reality always reduces everything back to practicality. The phone must work, the car must drive, the money must last. Illusions live only as long as the system allows the game of ‚Äústatus.‚Äù

Conclusion

People who live with perspective think in terms of the future: ‚ÄúHow will this work in a year, in ten years?‚Äù People who live in the illusion of the moment think in terms of ‚ÄúHow does this look right here and now?‚Äù Neither group disappears. They coexist. But when hard times come, illusions deflate quickly, and practicality takes the lead again.

üìå Life always asks the same question: do you live for real usefulness and convenience, or for appearances in someone else‚Äôs eyes? And that test is what separates reality from illusion.

posts.title_en: On Things and Show-Offs
posts.content_en:
The world of things used to be simple. A phone was made to call and be convenient. A car ‚Äî to drive you around. A watch ‚Äî to tell the time. The logic was clear: a thing should serve a person. But somewhere along the way, something went wrong.

Things as Tools

When an item does its job, it‚Äôs a good one. A phone with stable reception that doesn‚Äôt glitch. A car that starts in winter and gets you where you need to go. A watch that neither lags nor runs ahead. Here everything is straightforward: a thing exists for life.

Show-Offs as Illusion

In the world of show-offs, it‚Äôs the other way around: A phone becomes a status symbol, even if bought on credit. A car is chosen not for reliability, but to impress the neighbor. A watch turns into a ‚Äúpiece of gold on the wrist,‚Äù showing not the time but the ‚Äúimportance of its owner.‚Äù Here the thing stops being a tool. It becomes a label, ‚Äúproof of success.‚Äù In other words: showing off costs more than the thing itself.

The Price of Showing Off

When people buy for show, they pay not for usefulness but for illusion. A smartphone that differs from the previous model by 5% but costs twice as much. A car that looks sleek but spends more time in the shop than on the road. Clothes where the brand tag matters more than the quality of the fabric. The problem is that showing off always needs fuel. A new phone comes out ‚Äî the old one is no longer a ‚Äústatus.‚Äù A brand falls out of fashion ‚Äî the show-off value disappears with it. And so a person runs into debt, wasting resources just to maintain someone else‚Äôs picture. In the end, things own the person, not the other way around.

The Paradox of Success

‚ÄúOwning an iPhone means being successful.‚Äù But if that iPhone is bought on credit, the successful one is the bank, not the owner. That road doesn‚Äôt lead to freedom, but to debt slavery. Real success isn‚Äôt in having the ‚Äúright‚Äù thing, but in the freedom to use what‚Äôs convenient for you.

Conclusion

Things are meant to serve people. Show-offs flip it around ‚Äî people start serving things. So the choice is always simple: live for yourself, using practical, comfortable things; or live for others, chasing show-offs that will lose value tomorrow.

üìå The formula is simple: things make life easier, show-offs make it harder.

posts.title_en: Put Yourself in Someone Else‚Äôs Place: A Clear View Beyond Your Own Filters
posts.content_en:
Most people, instead of trying to understand others, measure their actions by their own standards: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd never do that.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy did he say that?‚Äù ‚ÄúShe must be stupid to act like that.‚Äù And that‚Äôs exactly where understanding ends. A person doesn‚Äôt see another ‚Äî only a reflection of themselves. True understanding begins when we step outside our own reactions and look through someone else‚Äôs eyes.

1. The Mechanism of Understanding

When we judge someone through the prism of our own experience, we see not them, but our own shadows. Empathy begins not when we pity someone, but when we allow ourselves to see the world as they do. Over a century ago, German philosopher Theodor Lipps introduced the concept of *Einf√ºhlung* ‚Äî literally ‚Äúfeeling into‚Äù another person. Modern neuroscience, through researchers like Jean Decety, has confirmed that empathy isn‚Äôt just poetic ‚Äî our brains literally mirror others‚Äô emotions. But for most people, that natural mechanism lies dormant, buried under ego, pride, and the need to be right.

2. The Habit of Judgment

When someone acts ‚Äúnot the way we would,‚Äù the inner judge wakes up. Instead of asking ‚Äúwhy?‚Äù, we rush to declare: ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt do that!‚Äù But the real question isn‚Äôt what you would do ‚Äî it‚Äôs why they did what they did. What in their life, fears, or past led to that choice? As philosopher Roman Krznaric wrote, empathy isn‚Äôt about agreement ‚Äî it‚Äôs about trying to understand motives, even when they seem foreign or uncomfortable.

3. Practice, Not Preaching

When you truly put yourself in another person‚Äôs place ‚Äî even for a moment ‚Äî judgment fades, and clarity appears. You stop seeing ‚Äúa bad person‚Äù and start seeing a person trying to survive within their own reality. And suddenly, the world feels less hostile. Dalai Lama XIV once said: ‚ÄúIf you want others to be happy, practice compassion. If you want to be happy yourself, practice compassion.‚Äù

4. Conclusion

Real understanding begins where judgment ends. Empathy isn‚Äôt weakness ‚Äî it‚Äôs a sign of maturity. Because only a mature person can admit: ‚ÄúMy truth isn‚Äôt the only one. Others have theirs too.‚Äù

posts.title_en: The Stone on the Path: On the Freedom of Choice, the Repetition of Experience, and the Silent Lessons of Being
Freedom Without Choice: The Human Between Illusion and Truth
Social Approval and Inner Integrity: From Dependence to Freedom
posts.content_en:
The need for social approval is one of the oldest and most deeply rooted human drives. From the moment a child first hears ‚Äúgood job,‚Äù the mind begins to link recognition with survival. People grow, change professions, appearances, and even beliefs ‚Äî yet the craving to be accepted often remains for life. The real issue begins when other people‚Äôs approval becomes the only proof of one‚Äôs own worth. This article explores the phenomenon of social approval through the lens of modern psychology and personal maturity. It examines how this dependency forms, the risks it carries, and the path toward genuine self-sufficiency ‚Äî a state that can be described as ethical autonomy.

1. The Nature of Social Approval

1.1. Biological Roots

Humans are social beings. In prehistoric tribes, rejection meant death. That‚Äôs why the human brain evolved to treat approval as a signal of safety and disapproval as a threat to survival. Neurobiologically, social approval activates the dopamine-based reward system ‚Äî the same one triggered by food or victory.

1.2. Psychological Definitions

In psychology, this phenomenon appears under several terms: Need for social approval ‚Äî the fundamental motivation to be accepted by others. Social desirability bias ‚Äî the tendency to behave or speak in ways that please others, even at the cost of one‚Äôs authenticity. External locus of control ‚Äî the belief that one‚Äôs value or success depends on others‚Äô opinions. Conformity ‚Äî adjusting behavior to align with group expectations for the sake of belonging. Affiliation need (McClelland) ‚Äî one of the core human needs: the drive to belong to a group. Each of these captures a different facet of the same mechanism ‚Äî the dependence of the self on external mirrors.

2. The Mechanics of Dependence

2.1. How It Forms

As children, we experience love and safety through approval. Gradually a conditional logic forms: ‚ÄúThey love me ‚Üí I‚Äôm good.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey disapprove ‚Üí Something‚Äôs wrong with me.‚Äù In adulthood this becomes an inner censor. The individual loses touch with genuine desire, filtering every impulse through imagined judgments of others.

2.2. The Pendulum Law: Praise and Rejection

Anyone who lives by praise automatically becomes vulnerable to criticism. The same source that elevates can destroy. This constant oscillation between euphoria and despair drains vitality ‚Äî because self-worth is outsourced to the crowd.

3. The Scale of Self-Sufficiency

  • **Level 1. Social.** Source of Value: Other people. Core Belief: ‚ÄúIf they value me, I exist.‚Äù
  • **Level 2. Self-aware.** Source of Value: Personal competence. Core Belief: ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm doing well.‚Äù
  • **Level 3. Authentic.** Source of Value: Inner self. Core Belief: ‚ÄúI act this way because it‚Äôs true to me.‚Äù
  • **Level 4. Creative-conscious.** Source of Value: Flow of being. Core Belief: ‚ÄúSomething greater expresses itself through me.‚Äù

Dependence on approval dominates the first two levels. Transition to the third marks the birth of an inner axis ‚Äî the ability to act from integrity rather than expectation.

4. The Void Beyond Approval: Fear and Wholeness

When a person faces the absence of external validation, a deep void appears ‚Äî the feeling that ‚Äúnothing is there.‚Äù It is not mere discomfort but existential panic: ‚ÄúIf no one sees me, do I even exist?‚Äù Most turn away at this threshold, retreating to familiar noise. Yet if one endures the silence ‚Äî without filling it with work, people, or distractions ‚Äî something remarkable happens: the true self begins to emerge. Not the role, not the function, but pure presence. What first feels like emptiness slowly becomes space. And in that space, genuine peace arises ‚Äî not the peace of escape, but the peace of being.

5. Ethical Autonomy: Living Without an Audience

Once external approval loses power, a person starts living by an inner moral compass ‚Äî not imposed by society but grounded in conscience. Example: ‚ÄúI turn on the blinker even when there‚Äôs no one else on the road.‚Äù That single gesture contains the essence of integrity. It‚Äôs not about rules ‚Äî it‚Äôs about internal coherence. You act rightly not because someone watches, but because anything else would feel false. This is ethical autonomy ‚Äî a stage where morality becomes organic, not reactive.

6. Maturity and Stillness

Wholeness doesn‚Äôt erase fear. The fear of death, of loss, of the unknown ‚Äî it remains, but it no longer commands. It becomes a quiet neighbor rather than a master. This is life lived from within reality, not in its anticipation. Such a person doesn‚Äôt say, ‚ÄúSomeday I‚Äôll start living.‚Äù They understand that life is already happening now, even when it looks ordinary or imperfect. Each moment ‚Äî even those spent waiting ‚Äî was life all along.

7. Conclusion

The need for social approval is not a flaw; it is a developmental stage. But staying there means living as a reflection, never as light itself. When a person shifts from external to internal grounding, approval becomes background noise. Then ethics, kindness, and professionalism cease to be performance ‚Äî they simply are. Integrity is when you behave the same way in darkness as if a light were shining on you.
